title: 106_s206
content: The "CHIP Data and Evaluation Improvement Act of 1999" aims to provide funding for reliable annual state-by-state estimates on the number of children without health insurance coverage. The Social Security Act is amended to include adjustments to the Current Population Survey for state-by-state data on low-income children without health insurance coverage, categorized by family income, age, and race/ethnicity. Adjustments made to produce state-by-state data on low-income children without health insurance coverage include expanding sample size and number of sampling units, with an appropriation of $10,000,000 for fiscal year 2000 and each fiscal year thereafter. Funding for children's health care access and utilization at the state level. Section 2108 of the Social Security Act is amended to collect data on children's health insurance through the State and Local Area Integrated Telephone Survey for all 50 states and the District of Columbia. Data will focus on health care access and utilization of children in low-income households, allowing for comparisons between demographic subgroups. The Secretary, through the Center, will design a survey on children's health insurance, with input from States. States may request additional data for program evaluation and must reimburse for these services. Appropriate funds are allocated for this purpose. Appropriated $9,000,000 for fiscal year 2000 and each fiscal year thereafter for carrying out this subsection. Federal evaluation of state children's health insurance programs is mandated by Section 4. Section 2108 of the Social Security Act mandates a federal evaluation of 10 States with approved child health plans, focusing on diverse approaches to child health assistance and including a significant portion of uncovered children. The federal evaluation of 10 States with approved child health plans includes surveys of the target population and evaluation of outreach and enrollment practices for children. The evaluation includes assessing State Medicaid eligibility practices, coordination between programs, effect of cost-sharing, and disenrollment factors for children enrolled in Medicaid under title XIX. The Secretary will evaluate disenrollment and retention issues for children enrolled in Medicaid under title XIX, including barriers in the recertification process. $10,000,000 is appropriated for the evaluation, with results to be submitted to Congress by December 31, 2001. Standardized reporting requirements for annual reports are outlined in Section 5. Section 2108(a) of the Social Security Act is amended to include standardized reporting requirements for annual reports, which must include enrollee counts categorized by income, age, and race or ethnicity. The curr_chunk describes the detailed eligibility methodologies used by the State for reporting income levels, including income disregards and exempted income. It also outlines the annual percentages of individuals enrolled in the program, Medicaid, or determined eligible but not enrolled. The curr_chunk states eligibility for the program or Medicaid under title XIX. Inspector General audit and GAO report on Medicaid eligibility for enrollees. The Social Security Act is amended to include an Inspector General audit and GAO report on Medicaid eligibility for enrollees, focusing on determining eligible enrollees and progress in reducing uncovered low-income children. The Social Security Act is amended to include monitoring by the Comptroller General of the United States on audits related to Medicaid eligibility for enrollees, specifically focusing on the number of uncovered low-income children in States without Medicaid coverage in their child health plans. SEC. 7 amends the Social Security Act to coordinate data collection with the Maternal and Child Health Services Block Grant. SEC. 8 establishes a clearinghouse for federal data on children's health.
